text: Psalm 53
The Folly of the Godless and Salvation for Israel
For the \add music\add* director, according to Mahalath.
A maskil of David.\f + \fr Ps 53 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one \f*
\add The\add* fool says in his heart, “There is no God.”
They are corrupt and they have done abominable iniquity.
There is none who does good.
God looks down from heaven upon the children of humankind
to see whether there is one who has insight,
one who seeks God.
⸤All of them⸥\f + \fr 53:3 \ft Literally “The whole of it,” i.e. all of humankind \f* have turned back.
They are altogether corrupt.
There is none who does good;
there is not even one.
Do not evildoers know,
\add they\add* who eat my people \add as though\add* they were eating bread?
They do not call on God.
There ⸤they are very fearful⸥\f + \fr 53:5 \ft Literally “they feared a fear” \f*
\add where\add* no fear had been,
because God has scattered the bones of him who encamps \add against\add* you.
You have put \add them\add* to shame, because God has rejected them.
⸤Oh, that from Zion⸥\f + \fr 53:6 \ft Literally “Who will give \fq that \ft from Zion” \f* would come salvation \add for\add* Israel!
When God returns the fortunes\f + \fr 53:6 \ft Or “captivity” \f* of his people,
let Jacob rejoice, let Israel be glad.
